title-group.article-title: Determinants of the Introduction of Stock Options by Japanese Firms: Analysis from the Incentive and Selection Perspectives*

abstract.p: This paper examines the determinants of the introduction of stock options in Japan, in response to their deregulation, from the incentive and selection perspectives. Younger firms use broad‐based stock options more often, even after controlling firm size, growth, and the possibility of a liquidity constraint. Moreover, stock price volatility increases the adoption of stock options only when a firm is young. These results support the relevancy of a selection view that focuses on efficient project choice. Stock options are used more often by fast‐growing firms and less in regulated industries and by the firms with concentrated ownership structure, consistent with both views.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The amendment of the Commercial Act in May 1997 deregulated the use of stock options as compensation tools in Japan. Before the amendment, the Japanese firms were effectively prohibited from using stock options, since the Commercial Act had prohibited the accumulation of treasury stocks through stock repurchase and imposed rigid rules on the issue of new stocks, the availability of either of which is necessary in the exercise phase of stock options.1An amendment to the law liberalized stock repurchase and enabled a flexible issue of new stocks, within the limit of 10% of outstanding stocks, for the purpose of introducing stock options.2The government also introduced a favorable tax treatment for stock options, allowing the postponement of taxation to the period when underlying stocks are sold, for qualified stock options. In response to these government measures, a large number of Japanese firms adopted stock options. Firms that have introduced stock options include Toyota, Mazda, Hitachi, Matsushita, Fujitsu, Mitsubishi Trading, Tanabe Seiyaku, Omron, and Kyocera.

A major policy objective of deregulating stock options is to improve the performance of firms by liberalizing the menu of compensation. The top management of a firm quite often justifies the introduction of stock options in the shareholders' meeting by stating that stock options enhance the motivation of the recipients and thereby enhance the performance of the firm.3However, the question of whether stock options can be accounted for by incentive theory (incentive is narrowly construed to be that for working hard, incurring personal cost of effort, in this paper, as in Lazear1999) is still unsettled. According to the estimate by Jensen and Murphy (1990), CEOs receive only $3.25 for every $1,000 increase in shareholder wealth.4Given that the top management of a firm has only such a small share of its outstanding stocks, any incentive effect of stock‐based compensation is likely to be diluted significantly, especially for a large firm.5The stock options for employees are harder to explain from an incentive theory, given that stock options expose them to the volatility of the stock price over which they have much less control.

Recently, a few authors offered an alternative but complementary explanation of output‐based pay. According to Lazear (1999), Prendergast (2000,2002), Oyer (2004), and Oyer and Schaefer (2005), output‐based pay such as stock options is used as a selection or sorting device in the environment of information asymmetry between a worker and a firm. According to Lazear (1999) and Prendergast (2000,2002), stock options induce the management delegated with investment decisions to select and implement only profitable projects for a firm. According to Lazear (1999), they also help a firm to attract able mangers and staff members who can select and implement investment projects efficiently. Similarly, according to Oyer (2004) and Oyer and Schaefer (2005), they help a firm sort optimistic workers and retain them by making compensation vary with labor market conditions. In addition, although not discussed by these authors, output‐based pay could also serve as an external signaling device to the investors, by which a firm with profitable investment opportunities can differentiate itself. From these perspectives, high‐powered output‐based pay is not necessary. Only the pay sufficiently linked to the output, so as to induce management to sort out good projects from bad, to attract only able managers and staff members, or to induce investors to sort out good firms from bad firms is necessary.

Substantive empirical analysis from this perspective has not yet been undertaken. The extensive literature review by Murphy (1999) reports no substantive empirical work done explicitly from this perspective. Yermack (1995) discusses a number of hypotheses based on an agency theory, including that of promoting efficient project choice. He, however, assumes that companies with large growth opportunities use stock‐based compensation for a project choice reason, even though such firm might also use stock options for an incentive reason, since the marginal value of the efforts of managers is likely to be high in such firms. More recent studies focus mainly on the correlation between stock price volatility and the adoption of stock options as evidence for a selection motivation. Oyer and Schaefer (2005) find a positive correlation between the stock price volatility of a firm and the incidence of broad‐based stock option plans and interpret it as a support to a sorting explanation. However, as summarized by Prendergast (2002), such correlation is often negative or absent from data with respect to executive incentives in the literature. This absence of a clear correlation may not be surprising, since stock‐price volatility can indicate both the size of a business risk, which is exogenous to the worker and the firm, and the size of information asymmetry between them.

This paper aims at examining empirically how the incentive and selection views can explain the introduction of stock options by Japanese firms in response to the deregulation of stock options. This study has three major new points in addition to the fact that it is the first comprehensive study on the introduction of stock options by Japanese firms. First, we introduce the age of a firm and the cross‐term of age and volatility as the indicators of the degree of information asymmetry between a worker and a firm (or investors in the case where the worker is top management) on project choices, which would help us in evaluating the importance of a selection view. Second, we use the distinction of stock repurchases and new issues in issuing stock options to control the liquidity reason for stock option. Such distinction existed in Japan due to the regulatory constraint on Treasury stock. Third, the adoption of stock options by Japanese firms is a response to its deregulation, so that we can be less worried about the endogeneity of independent variables such as the financial leverage and the dividend policy of a firm.

More specifically, with respect to the first point, we attempt to assess the role of stock options as a selection device by examining whether the age of a firm, an indicator of the smallness of information asymmetry between a worker and a firm on investment opportunities, has a negative effect on the adoption decisions of stock options, following the suggestion by Lazear (1999). We also use three new approaches. First, we evaluate whether the age of a firm has a significantly smaller effect for the firms listed in the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, for which information asymmetry presumably is less important. Second, we evaluate whether the positive effect of stock‐price volatility on the adoption of stock options declines with the age of a firm, by estimating the effect of the cross‐term of volatility and age, since it is likely that the extent to which stock‐price volatility indicates information asymmetry is larger for a younger firm. Third, we evaluate whether the age of a firm affects the adoption probability of a broad‐based stock option covering employees more than that of a narrow‐based stock option granted only to the top management. Stock options based on a selection reason are likely to be more broad based, since not only top management but also lower‐level management is likely to have important private information on investment projects, when a firm has broad investment opportunities.

There is an identification issue in interpreting the age of a firm as a measure of information asymmetry. Since a young firm is more likely to have large growth opportunities and a small size, it may be more likely to use stock options than an old firm for an incentive reason, too, although higher risk in such firm can offset such motivation significantly.6In addition, since such firm is more likely to face a liquidity constraint, it is more likely to use stock options in compensation to save cash. This paper controls such possibilities by introducing variables representing the size and growth of a firm as well as its financial situation and by estimating equations separately for stock options based on stock repurchases and those based on new issues. Since a liquidity‐constrained firm is very unlikely to choose stock repurchase, the estimation focusing on the subsample of the firms that have chosen stock repurchase would be free from the potential bias due to the correlation between the age of a firm and the possibility of a liquidity constraint.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II provides the descriptive statistics of stock options in Japan, showing their main characteristics. Section III presents a theoretical framework. Section IV discusses the major empirical determinants of stock options and provides a framework of statistical estimation. Section V provides estimation results, and Section VI concludes.

fn.p: Some firms, such as Sony, had introduced quasi‐stock options for their directors and employees, using bonds with warranties, even before the deregulation of stock options. However, firms that cannot issue bonds cannot use such a scheme. Moreover, the quasi‐stock option is expensive due to the necessity of involving a financial intermediary.

The Commercial Act was further amended in October 2001, which resulted in further deregulation of the repurchase of stocks by abolishing the restrictions on the maximum number of treasury stocks that can be held, relative to outstanding stocks, and on the period during which the Treasury stocks can be held.
In a small number of cases, top management refers to the recruitment of able workers as a justification of stock options.

However, some case studies, such as Dial and Murphy (1995) and Lazear (2000), suggest that incentive works effectively.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Data Sources
sec.p: The information on the introduction of stock options by Japanese firms is based on the decisions in the shareholders' meetings from May 1997 to June 2000, as reported by Shouji‐Homu journals. They cover both the firms listed in the 11 Japanese stock exchanges and the firms whose shares are traded over the counter (OTC firms). The financial and other corporate information of these firms at the end of the fiscal year (mostly March) are collected from the NEEDS (Nikkei Economic Electronic Database System) and the Japan Company Handbook of Toyo‐Keizai, except for monthly stock price returns, which are from the Japan Securities Research Institute.7We cover all business sectors except for banking and insurance. We integrated these data from different sources based on the security code of each company. There exist 3,176 firms in our database and 391 of them had adopted stock options by June 2000. Eighteen of these firms had implemented only the amendment of corporate charters, authorizing their management to issue stock options.

fn.p: Stock price returns published by the Japan Securities Research Institute reflect not only capital gain but also dividends and the effects of stock splits.

sec.title: Characteristics of Option Contracts
sec.p:

The waiting time until options become exercisable (or vested) is short. Of the option awards, 98% have a waiting period of 3 years or less, for which the unambiguous dates for the end of waiting time are available. Fast‐growing firms tend to have short waiting times. The terms of the options are short, compared to those in the United States. While the majority of the options in the United States have a 10‐year term (Murphy1999), 85 % of the option awards in Japan have a term of 5 years or less. The term of options could not exceed 10 years in Japan, due to the legal constraint imposed by the Commercial Act until October 2001. Firms with large foreign ownership tend to have longer terms.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Incentive and Selection Views of Stock Options
sec.p: This section summarizes the main logic and implications of the incentive and selection theories on the adoption of stock options. In the following discussions, a firm means the principal of a worker, so that it implies the group of investors to the firm when the worker is in top management. An incentive theory considers the situation where both a firm and a worker know what a worker should do (i.e., his task) but the monitoring of his effort is costly. The output‐based pay has the advantage of creating an internal incentive for a worker to enhance his effort, without incurring the monitoring cost. On the other hand, it has the disadvantage of forcing the risk‐averse worker to bear a risk that he cannot control and the firm can bear more efficiently. The optimal intensity of the incentive is determined to strike the best balance between more effort and more risk bearing by the worker (see Stiglitz1975and Milgrom and Roberts1992). The incentive view has the following implication on when a stock option is used.

Proposition1. A stock option is more likely to be used for an incentive reason when the monitoring of the effort of a worker is ineffective or costly or when the volatility of the value of the firm due to the risk exogenous to the worker is small.

A selection theory, on the other hand, considers the situation where a worker has the private information that enables him to select the project with the highest value among the candidate projects, which look identical to the firm ex ante. The output‐based pay combined with the delegation of project choice to the worker can induce him to select the right project to implement, and such pay need not be large if the variation of the private benefits from projects is small (see Hirshleifer and Suh1992; Lazear1999; and Prendergast2000,2002). The selection theory has the following implication on when a stock option is used.

Proposition2. A stock option is used for a selection reason, even if it is not justified for an incentive reason, when a firm has broad investment opportunities and the worker has a significant information advantage with respect to the project selection.

These propositions have implications on who in a firm receives stock options. Both propositions suggest that the top management of a firm is more likely to receive stock options. From an incentive view, monitoring the effort of top management is less effective and the top management has more control over the business risk of the firm. From a selection view, top management has the largest discretion within the firm. However, the two views may have different implications on how broad based the stock option is. From an incentive view, a broad‐based stock option is hard to justify, given that a low‐level worker has to bear a large risk for the stock option to be effective. From a selection view, a stock option may still make sense if a low‐level worker can make a difference in project choice, and a small amount of output‐based pay can induce his efficient project selection.

The output‐based pay can be used not only to induce efficient project selection by a worker but also to screen the workers or the firms with good investment projects from those without. That is, it can be used as a screening or signaling device. The firm can select the workers who have the capability to propose good projects by requiring them to receive stock options as a part of their compensation.9The investors can select the firms that have good project plans by requiring the workers of the firms to receive stock options as a part of their compensation. These motivations for output‐based pay are important when firms and workers are heterogeneous and the information asymmetry with respect to their qualities is large.

fn.p: The selection motivation may also arise due to the heterogeneity in the expectation of employees with respect to the future value of the firm (see Oyer and Schaefer2005).

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Other Determinants
sec.p: While this paper focuses on the incentive and selection views, there are two other important motivations for adopting stock options. The first one is the liquidity constraint of a firm. A cash‐constrained firm may use stock options as a substitute for cash compensation (see Core and Guay2001). We incorporate this possibility in our empirical analysis. The second one is retention of employees. Since options have a vesting period, they increase the costs of quitting the firm to employees. The correlation between the value of stock options and the tightness of labor market conditions may make stock options an efficient instrument for this objective (see Oyer2004). This reason, however, is not very important in Japan, where the quitting, especially by the managers, is not very common and the waiting time for the stock option is short.

sec.title: Age (age)
sec.p: An important implication of the selection view is that we observe a higher incidence of stock options among younger firms, since information asymmetry between a manager and investors with respect to investment opportunities is likely to decline with firm age (Lazear1999) Thus, the age of a firm negatively affects the probability of adopting stock options. In addition, such effect is weaker if a firm is already listed in the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, since the business activities of the firms listed in that exchange tend to be well known to investors. Thus, we expect that the firm listed on that exchange has a smaller slope coefficient of age. Conversely, it would be larger for the OTC firms. Furthermore, since the stock options granted for a selection reason is likely to be more broad based, we expect the firm age to reduce the probability of broad‐based stock options but not necessarily the probability that only directors are granted stock options.

The age of a firm is likely to be correlated with the abundance of its growth opportunities and its firm size. A young firm tends to grow fast, as shown by the failure of Gibrat's law for such firms (see Sutton1997), and tends to be small. The abundance of growth opportunities and a small size may encourage a young firm to adopt stock options as an incentive reason too. In addition, such firm is likely to have a higher probability of facing liquidity constraints. We control these effects by introducing the independent variables representing these channels in our estimation. If we are successful in controlling these factors, an incentive view could actually suggest that the incidence of stock options increase with age, since a younger firm tends to face higher risk.

sec.title: Stock‐Price Volatility and its Interaction with Age (mvolandagemvol)
sec.p: The second important implication of a selection view is that we could observe higher incidence of stock options for the firms with high‐stock price volatility (Prendergast2002). The incentive view, on the other hand, suggests a negative relationship between the two. The stock‐price volatility of a firm generally indicates both the size of the business risk, which is exogenous to the firm and the worker, and the size of information asymmetry between them. However, the extent of stock‐price volatility that reflects the information asymmetry is likely to be larger when the firm is younger. Therefore, we expect stock‐price volatility to increase the use of stock options more when the firm is young, if the selection reason is important. Hence, we expect the volatility of the stock price to have a positive coefficient and the cross‐term of the age and volatility to have a negative coefficient, if the selection reason is important. This specification of the effects of volatility may help reconcile the conflicting empirical results on the effects of volatility on the managerial ownership or on stock options in past studies (Aggarwal and Samwick1999and Himmelberg, Hubbard, and Palia 1999 found a negative correlation, while Demsetz and Lehn1985; Core and Guay2001; and Oyer and Schaefer2005found a positive correlation).

sec.title: Growth and R&D opportunities (glandrds)
sec.p: The growth and R&D opportunities of a firm tend to increase the adoption probability of stock options from a selection reason, since the opportunities for selecting investment projects as well as the degree of information asymmetry between the workers and the firm tends to be large for such firm. Option‐based compensation motivates a manager to exploit investment opportunities when they appear (Hirshleifer and Suh1992). From an incentive view, the growth and R&D opportunities of a firm have ambiguous effects. They tend to increase the effect of management efforts on the value of firms, since a firm with more of these opportunities builds tangible and intangible resources more quickly within it, the value of which complements managerial efforts. In addition, R&D‐intensive industries have long‐term payoffs and workers must be motivated by compensation structures that take a longer‐run view, such as stock options.10These effects enhance the incentive reason for stock options. On the other hand, the growth and R&D opportunities of a firm are positively correlated with its level of exogenous business risk. In addition, the growth opportunities of a firm strengthen the incentive for its manager to establish and retain his reputation, so that the effectiveness of effort monitoring could also increase. These two effects tend to reduce the use of output‐based pay for an incentive reason.

fn.p: I owe this point to the referee.

sec.title: Regulation and the other Industry Characteristics
sec.p: Regulation and the other industry characteristics, such as technological opportunities, demand growth, and their volatilities, affect the costs and benefits of stock options. We control such characteristics by 10 industry dummies in our empirical work. In regulated industries, both incentive and selection reasons work against stock options. The incentive reason for stock options is weak, since the profit incentive itself is weak and the regulator plays a substantial role of monitoring and disciplining of the management in such industries (Demsetz and Lehn1985). The selection reason is also weak, not only due to weak profit motivation but also due to the smaller discretion by management.

sec.title: Firm Size (lnlabor)
sec.p: The size of a firm has an ambiguous effect on the introduction of stock options from an incentive point of view, as far as those to top management are concerned. In a large firm, the monetary value of the exogenous risk is large for a given amount of stock‐price volatility,11but simultaneously, the marginal effect of the effort of top management is likely to be large. The former factor clearly weakens the case for stock options, while the latter factor enhances it if we assume that monitoring is inefficient for top management. Firm size has an ambiguous effect from a selection view, too. In a large firm, the scope and the value of the discretionary behavior of top management are large, as emphasized by Himmelberg et al. (1999), but the information asymmetry between the management and the investors could also be small in such firm, since the information on such a firm is more likely to be reported.

fn.p: The volatility of firm value (ó) is proportional to the product of the stock‐price volatility (mvol) and firm size. Note that, even if firms A and B have identical stock‐price volatility, a manager in large firm A faces a larger risk in terms of certainty than in a small firm, even if+the two firms have the same incentive intensity.

sec.title: Ownership Structure (mstop,fo)
sec.p: Concentrated ownership reduces the free‐rider problem in monitoring the management. Thus, it weakens the incentive reason for adopting stock options. In addition, concentrated ownership helps reducing the free‐rider problem of investors in acquiring information, so that a selection reason for stock options also is weaker. We use the combined shares of the top 10 major stockholders (mstop) as a measure of ownership concentration. Finally, foreign ownership (fo) may facilitate the use of stock options, since they are widely used as a mean of management compensation in foreign countries, especially in the United States.12

fn.p: See Murphy (1999) for an extensive review of management compensation practices in developed economies.

sec.title: Liquidity Constraints and Accounting Profitability (rdividend,nprofitrate)
sec.p: Stock options based on new issues provide a firm with the means of cashless compensation. Thus, a liquidity‐constrained firm may substitute stock options for cash compensation, as pointed out by Yermack (1995) among others. We use dividend rate (rdividend= dividends divided by the book value of capital) to measure the probability of a liquidity constraint as perceived by a firm. The accounting profitability of firms (nprofitrate= after‐tax income divided by the book value of capital, i.e., return on equity) as well as the financial leverage (to be explained next) may also contribute to capturing the probability of liquidity constraints on a firm, since dividend rate cannot become negative. The liquidity reason for stock options is absent for stock options based on stock repurchase, since the latter requires cash. Therefore, we expect that a liquidity constraint has no significant effect on the probability of adopting stock options based on stock repurchases. The shareholders may become more willing to authorize the use of stock options when the accounting profitability of the firm is high. Thus, from a theoretical point of view, the accounting profitability has an ambiguous sign.

sec.title: Financial Leverage (da)
sec.p: High leverage itself can be a significant inducement for a manager to work hard and identify profitable projects, since bankruptcy is generally costly for management (Jensen1993). In addition, in a firm with high financial leverage, stock‐price‐based incentives increase the agency cost of debt through encouraging management to choose riskier investments (John and John1993). Moreover, when financial leverage is high, the stock price of a firm becomes more volatile, although this could be controlled by the volatility variable. Thus, financial leverage reduces the use of stock options in both views. On the other hand, high financial leverage can indicate a shortage of cash, which can encourage a firm to use stock options as a part of compensation to save cash. Since a firm facing a liquidity constraint does not repurchase stocks, these considerations suggest that financial leverage reduces the use of the stock options based on stock repurchase, but it may increase the use of the stock options based on new issues.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Empirical Specifications
sec.p:
The general specification we use for evaluating the determinants of stock options is given by

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Estimation Results
sec.p: First, let us take a look at the results of probit estimation, reported intable 6. The age of a firm negatively affects the probability of introducing stock options and is highly significant at the 1% level in the first three estimations based on the full sample. According to the marginal effect, 10 years difference in firm age affects the probability by 3.8% for a firm not listed in the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange. In addition, the negative effect ofageis significantly smaller at the 1% level when a firm is listed in the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The size of the coefficient of age is almost twice as large for the firms not listed in the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange as the firms listed in that exchange (−0.021 vs. −0.009 according to estimation 2). Thus, the usefulness of stock options is large for young firms, and the effect ofageis stronger for the firms not listed in the first section of Tokyo Stock Exchange, providing significant support to the selection view. On the other hand, it is found that neither the slope dummy nor the intercept difference for the OTC firms is significant.

In the estimations based on the sample of the firms listed in the Tokyo Stock Exchange (first or second section), the stock‐price volatility of a firm (mvol) has a positive but insignificant coefficient in estimation 4 with no interaction with the term age. However, it has a positive and significant coefficient (at 5%) in estimation 5, which has interaction. Since the interaction of age and volatility has a significantly negative coefficient (at 5%), the effect of market volatility on the probability of adopting stock options is positive only for a young firm. The estimation results suggest that stock‐price volatility enhances the adoption of stock options for a firm less than 61 years old.13These results support the view that the stock price volatility represents greater information asymmetry between investors and managers for younger firms and provides additional support to the importance of a selection motivation.

Growth (gl) has a highly significant and positive coefficient (1% level), while R&D intensity (rds) is not significant at the 5% level in all equations, although it has a positive coefficient. The dummies for four industries—regulated industries, construction, basic materials, and food—have significantly negative coefficients at the 1% level. Construction, basic materials, and food are three of the four least R&D‐intensive sectors (seetable 3), with the average R&D intensity being less than 1%. These results support the importance of a selection motivation for stock options in R&D‐intensive sectors and their weakness in regulated industries. However, they can also be consistent with an incentive view.

Firm size (lnlabor) has an insignificant (negative) coefficient in estimation 1. However, estimation 2 shows that its square has a positive and highly significant coefficient, indicating the U‐shaped impact of firm size on the probability of introducing stock options. As firm size increases, the probability of introducing stock options initially declines, then increases again. Estimation 3 shows that the cubic term does not have a significant coefficient and the square term remains significant, so that the U‐shaped relationship seems to be robust. The bottom of the U‐shaped impact is reached at 2,000 in employment, according to estimation 2. One possible interpretation of this U‐shaped pattern would be that a small firm needs a stock option as a signaling device to investors but such necessity becomes smaller when its size becomes larger and its reputation increases, for a given firm age. However, when it becomes very large, it may need stock options, since the room for discretionary conduct by management and its economic value become large.

The ownership concentration to the top 10 shareholders (mstop) has a significantly negative effect at the 1% level. This result is consistent with both incentive and selection theories, in that strong monitoring substitutes the provision of output‐based incentive or better information gained by major shareholders reduces the necessity of a selection device based on stock options. Foreign ownership (fo) has a positive, although not significant, coefficient.

Dividend rate has a negative coefficient in all equations and significant at 5% level in estimations 2 and 3. This finding that a low dividend rate has a positive correlation with the probability of adopting stock options is consistent with a liquidity reason for stock options. Accounting profitability has negative and significant coefficients in estimations 4 and 5, which may also indicate a liquidity reason.The debt/asset ratio (da) has a negative but insignificant coefficient.

To examine the possibility that firm‐specific missing variables, such as the ability of the managers, may cause a bias in estimation due to their possible correlation with independent variables, we undertook a supplementary regression in which management stock ownership (mso) is added as an independent variable, which would control the effect of missing variables affecting the adoption of stock options. The results are largely consistent with the previous results (see estimation 2 of thetable A2), suggesting that these results are robust with respect to the potential bias due to missing firm variables.

Next, let us turn to the multinomial regressions, reported intable 7. Estimation 1 differentiates the stock options based on stock repurchase and new issues. There are two important findings. First, younger firms are more likely to issue stock options, even if they have to repurchase stocks. This finding clearly shows that the possibility of liquidity constraints cannot account for the negative effect of firm age on stock options. Second, a firm with high financial leverage is less likely to issue the stock options based on stock repurchase, while such a firm is more likely to issue the stock options based on new issues compared with a firm with low financial leverage. These finding suggests the importance of a liquidity reason for stock options.

The second multinomial regression analyzes the determinants of the recipients of stock options, differentiating the broad‐based stock options covering employees and the narrow ones only for directors. There are two important findings. First, the age of a firm negatively affects the probability of adopting stock options only when stock options cover employees. This is consistent with a prediction of the selection view pointed out earlier. When a firm has broad investment opportunities, not only top management but also lower‐level management are likely to have important private information useful for project selection. Second, the size of a firm (log of the employment size) affects the introduction of stock options positively and uniformly when they are targeted to directors, but it has a U‐shaped impact, as before, when they cover employees. A possible interpretation of the difference is that the stock options targeted to directors reflect mainly the incentive reason, while the broad‐based stock options mainly reflect the selection reason. The incentive reason for the top management may become stronger monotonically as the firm size increases. On the other hand, the selection reason may initially decline as the investors gain more information with respect to the firm as the firm size increases but may increase again as the discretion of the workers of the firm increases.

fn.p: A parallel implication is that age negatively affects the adoption of stock options only when the market volatility is more than 4.9% per month.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Conclusions and Discussions
sec.p:
This paper examined empirically the determinants of the introduction of stock options in Japan, in response to their deregulation in 1997, from the incentive and selection perspectives. In particular, it examined whether a selection theory, based on the information asymmetry between a worker and a firm with respect to project choices, is relevant. We found three importance pieces of evidence, pointing to the importance of a selection motivation:
1.
Even if we control firm size, growth, and the possibility of a liquidity constraint and focus on the sample of the stock options based on stock repurchase, younger firms use stock options more often than older firms. The effect of the firm age on the probability of adopting stock options is smaller for the firms listed in the first section of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, for which information asymmetry is likely to be least important. These results seem to be robust with respect to firm‐level missing variables, since a supplementary regression in which the management stock ownership is added as an independent variable is found to produce the qualitatively same results.
2.
The stock‐price volatility of a firm increases the probability of adopting stock options only when a firm is young. Since the degree of stock‐price volatility to indicate information asymmetry is likely to be larger when a firm is younger, this provides an additional support to the importance of a selection reason. This finding may help reconciling the conflicting empirical results on the effects of volatility on managerial ownership or stock options in past studies.
3.
Firm age negatively affects the probability of adopting stock options only when the stock options granted cover employees. This is consistent with a prediction of a selection view, since when a firm has broad investment opportunities, not only the top management but also the lower‐level management is likely to have important private information useful for project selection.

Other major findings include the the finding that stock options are more often used by fast‐growing firms and more in R&D‐intensive industries and less in regulated industries. These results are consistent with a selection theory but also can be consistent with an incentive view. Consistent with both theories, they are used less often by the firms with a concentrated ownership structure. A firm with a liquidity constraint is more likely to use stock options.

This paper suggests several future research issues. The first issue is the decomposition of the sources of stock price volatility. Our research suggests that the volatility reflects more strongly the information asymmetry (relative to the exogenous business risk) when a firm is young. This, however, needs further investigation and confirmation. The second issue is the cause of the nonmonotonic impact of firm size on the adoption of stock options. Our research suggests that, as firm size increases, the probability of granting stock options increases uniformly when they are targeted to the directors but such probability follows a U‐shaped form when they cover employees. The reason for such a nonmonotonic relationship needs to be clarified and may be related to the different sources of information asymmetry.

app.label: Appendix A
app.title: Definition of Independent Variables
app.p: The employment growth (gl) of a firm is the average growth rate from 1990FY (FY = fiscal year, starting April 1) to 1996 FY. The R&D intensity of a firm (rds) is given by its R&D expenditure divided by its sales. Many firms (more than half the firms in our database) do not publicly report R&D expenditures.14Since most of these nonreporting firms either belong to distribution, services, construction, or a regulated industry or are small in size,15they are unlikely to do substantive internal R&D. Given these considerations, we assign zeros for R&D intensity for nonreporting firms and include a dummy variable for such firms (rdum) to control a possible divergence of its mean from zero. This procedure is justified, since simply eliminating observations results in a significant reduction of the sample size and the introduction of a possible sample selection bias.16

We use 10 industry dummies in our estimation, with textile and other manufacturing industries serving as the basis (seetable 3). We use the industry affiliation of a firm as given by the NEEDS database. Regulated industries are defined as electricity, gas, communications, and transportation. Of the sample, 9.5% firms belong to a regulated industry. Age of a firm (age) is the difference between 1997 and the establishment year of a firm, the latter of which is from the Japan Company Handbook of Toyo‐Keizai.

The stock price volatility (mvol) is given by a standard deviation of monthly return for the 3‐year period from 1994FY to 1996FY. With respect to foreign ownership, we assign zeros for nonreported foreign‐held stocks, since a nonreporting firm is small in size and unlikely to have substantial foreign ownership17and include the dummy (fodum) for such firm in estimations, to control a possible divergence of its mean from zero.

Independent variables, in principle, are those in 1996 FY, that is, a year before the deregulation of stock options in Japan.18However, for the firms whose data on ownership structure are missing for 1996FY, I use data either for 1997FY, 1998FY, or 1999FY. We have 2,406 firms for which we can obtain data for all these independent variables, excluding some outlier cases.19

fn.p: Only 42% of the firms in the NEEDS database report R&D expenditures in 1996 FY.
Of the firms with no reported R&D figures, 97% either belong to these four sectors or have employment less than 2,000.

Estimation based on a limited sample results in significantly less precision of the estimated coefficients, although the coefficients of age, the size of firm squared, industry dummies for regulated industries and construction remain significant (available on request).
There are 65 such firms in our sample for regression analysis and the average labor size is between 370 and 1,400.
The 1996FY ends in March 1997 for the majority of firms. For the other firms, we chose the date so that they end earlier than March 1997 but as close to that month as possible.
We exclude those samples where foreign ownership or the combined share of the top 10 major shareholders exceeds 100(%).

app.label: Appendix B
app.title: Management Stockholdings and Adoption of Stock Options
app.p:
This appendix shows the results of two supplementary estimations. Estimation 1 oftable A2reports the estimation results with the management stockholdings relative to the outstanding stocks in 1999 FY (mso_99) as the dependent variable (the transformed form:tmso_99= 100 × ln[100/(100‐mso_99)]). The estimated results are largely the same as those for stock options in terms of the signs and significance of the coefficients. In particular,agehas a significantly negative effect and its effect is significantly smaller for the firms listed in the first section of Tokyo Stock Exchange, and growth (gl) has a significantly positive effect. In addition, firm size has a U‐shaped impact on the amount of the management stockholding. Furthermore, the sign of the coefficient of the dividend rate is the same as that for stock options. These results support our expectation that management stockholdings and stock options have similar determinants, given that the basic costs and benefits of two compensation forms are similar, although they are not perfect substitutes for each other.20

There exist two significant differences in the estimated coefficients. First, the coefficient of the concentration of ownership to the top 10 shareholders is positive for management stockholding. This result may not be surprising, since managers are often major shareholders in smaller firms. The second major difference is that foreign ownership has a significantly negative coefficient on management stockholding. The positive coefficient of the ownership concentration suggests that the reason for the negative effect of the age of a firm on the management stockholding is different from that for the stock option. The share of management stockholding may well decline as the firm becomes mature or as its size increases, simply because the owner‐manager sells his closely held stocks to the public, as the lemon's discount falls.

Estimation 2 shows the probit estimation of the probability of adopting stock options, adding the management shareholding relative to the outstanding stock in 1996FY (mso_99) as an additional independent variable. It picks up the missing firm‐specific variables determining the adoption of stock options, which may bias the estimations. According to the estimation, the variable mso has a highly significant positive coefficient. Moreover, the major variables have the same signs and significance as estimation 2 intable 6, although the sizes of the coefficient have declined. Thus, the main conclusions derived from the estimations intable 6look to be robust to the missing firm specific variables.

fn.p: Most important, a manager‐owner has no choice but to hold a significant part of his company's stocks until his firm has established a reputation in the capital market, while he is not forced to own stock options. In addition, since stock options have asymmetric payoffs, they may compensate the risk aversion of management more effectively (Hirshleifer and Suh1992).
